{{Tone|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Heather Dewey-Hagborg |image=DNA Spoofing - 2.jpg |caption=Heather Dewey-Hagborg (photo from her 2013 project ''DNA Spoofing'') | birth_date = June 4, 1982 | birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | residence = [[Chicago, Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Information artist | alma_mater = New York University | notable works = Stranger Visions | website = http://deweyhagborg.com | module = {{Listen |embed=yes| filename = Dewey-Hagborg.ogg| title = Heather Dewey-Hagborg Voice| type = speech| description = recorded in August 2014}} }}
'''Heather Dewey-Hagborg''' (born June 4, 1982, [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]) is an information artist and [[Do-it-yourself biology|bio-hacker]].<ref name="Brodwin, E."/> She is most noted for her project [[#Stranger Visions|''Stranger Visions'']]: a series of portraits created from [[DNA]] she recovered from discarded items, such as hair, cigarettes and chewing gum while living in [[Brooklyn, New York]].<ref name="Aldous, Peter"/> She sequenced the DNA at the Brooklyn open [[biotechnology]] laboratory, [[Genspace]].<ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Wilson Center"/> From the extracted DNA, she determined gender, ethnicity and other factors and then used face-generating software and a [[3D printer]] to create a speculative, algorithmically determined 3D portrait. While critical of technology and surveillance, her work has been found disturbing by some critics.<ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/04/tech/innovation/dna-face-sculptures/ Natalie Angley, "Artist creates faces from DNA left in public"], CNN.com, September 4, 2013.</ref>
==Education== [[File:Spurious Memories.jpg|thumb|''Spurious Memories'' (2007)]] Dewey-Hagborg is an information and bio artist whose works explore the intersection between art and science.<ref name="Colanduno, D.">{{cite web|last1=Colanduno|first1=Derek|authorlink=Derek Colanduno|title=Pieces of You #223|url=http://www.skepticality.com/piecesofyou|website=Skepticality|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=December 31, 2013}}</ref> As a student in the Information Arts program at [[Bennington College]],<ref name="Wilkinson, A.">{{cite journal|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Alec|title=Mask Crusader|journal=New Yorker|date=July 1, 2013|volume=89|issue=19|pages=22–23|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/07/01/mask-crusader|accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref> she participated in computer science classes, which laid the groundwork for the science-based artwork she would later envision using [[algorithms]], [[electronics]], and [[computer programming]].<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> She earned a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in 2003.
Dewey-Hagborg continued refining her work as an artist and computer programmer, studying [[artificial intelligence]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> while obtaining a Master of Professional Studies (M.P.S.) in Interactive Telecommunications from [[New York University]] (NYU)<ref name="Schwendener1">{{cite news|last1=Schwendener|first1=Martha|title=Populism, Technology, and Interactivity|publisher=The New York Times|date=August 28, 2011}}</ref> in 2007. It was here she curated a robotic performance art show called ''Robots on the March!'' in March 2005, and exhibited a piece called ''Lighter than Air: an experiment in constructing an autonomous flying robot''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Photosynthesis and Experiments in Sustainable Robotics|url=http://www.atasite.org/calendar/archive/index-24133.html|website=Artists' Television Access|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=March 25 – April 30, 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Lighter Than Air|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eJmu-AzrXH4|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref>
As a final project at NYU, Dewey-Hagborg explored the question "Can computers be creative?" in an exhibit she called Spurious Memories. She developed an autonomous face categorizing and generating software program which recognized facial components, made comparisons and adjustments, and produced unique representations of the human face through mass exposure to facial images.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Spurious Memories|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1elpx1rz_R0|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=April 16, 2011}}</ref>
After graduating from NYU, she became a doctoral candidate in electronics arts at [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]]<ref name="Dawsey, J">{{cite news|last1=Dawsey|first1=Josh|title=Art emerges from DNA left behind|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324281004578352473833386586|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|issue=Eastern Edition|date=March 11, 2013|page=A19}}</ref><ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Squires, A.">{{cite web|last1=Squires|first1=Acacia|title=Litterbugs beware: turning found DNA into portraits|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/05/12/183363361/litterbugs-beware-turning-found-dna-into-portraits|website=NPR|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=May 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Rodrigo, N.">{{cite web|last1=Rodrigo|first1=Nandi|title=Faces in the Crowd, Printed in 3-D|url=http://6thfloor.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/08/faces-in-the-crowd-printed-in-3-d/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|website=The New York Times Blog|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=May 31, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Herper, M.">{{cite news|last1=Herper|first1=Matthew|title=Artist Creates Portraits from People's DNA. Scientists Say 'That's Impossible'|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2013/05/31/turning-found-dna-into-portraits-what-an-imagination|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=Forbes|date=May 31, 2013}}</ref> and is expected to graduate in 2016.
Dewey-Hagborg has worked as a teaching assistant at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute,<ref name=Dewey-Hagborg>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=CV|url=http://www.deweyhagborg.com/art_resume.pdf|website=deweyhagborg|accessdate=August 5, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140827212543/http://deweyhagborg.com/art_resume.pdf|archivedate=August 27, 2014|df=}}</ref> an adjunct professor at NYU's Interactive Telecommunications Program,<ref>{{cite web|title=Interactive Telecommunication|website=Tisch School of the Arts|publisher=New York University|accessdate=August 5, 2014|page=152|year=2011–2013}}</ref> and an adjunct professor at NYU's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences.<ref name=Dewey-Hagborg/><ref name="MoMa PS1"/>
As of August 2014, Dewey-Hagborg resides in [[Chicago, Illinois]], teaching art and technology studies at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Art and Technology Studies: Faculty|url=http://www.saic.edu/profiles/faculty/heatherdewey-hagborg|website=School of the Art Institute of Chicago|accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref> As an educator her areas of interest include art and technology, multimedia, digital photography, research-based art and programming, and computer science.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name=Dewey-Hagborg/>
==Selected projects== ===Totem=== [[File:Heather Dewey-Hagborg Totem.jpg|thumb|''Totem'' (2010)]] Dewey-Hagborg's ''Totem'' (2010) was a site-specific multimedia sculpture characterizing her earlier work. ''Totem'', an idol, was designed to explore the implications of language and artificial intelligence using [[machine learning]] technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Event Guide July thru December 2011|url=http://issuu.com/groundsforsculpture/docs/summerfall2011|website=ISSUU.com|accessdate=August 5, 2014|page=15}}</ref> Exploiting audio surveillance techniques to eavesdrop on and record conversations at the installation site, Dewey-Hagborg wrote algorithms to then isolate word sequences and grammatical structures into commonly used units. Influenced by [[Hebbian theory]], she programmed the sculpture's computer to generate speech based on the most frequently occurring language structures in any given recording period. Over time, the least frequently elicited words or units would fade or be dropped from the sculpture's spoken vocabulary. The remaining units, stored in the sculpture's memory, were then spoken at random intervals.<ref name=Totem/>
The piece also reflected the writings of psychologist [[Julian Jaynes]]. According to Dewey-Hagborg, Jaynes theorized that an early form of human consciousness evolved as a result of hallucinated speech experienced by the Mari civilization of the [[Euphrates]]. The ancient people interpreted water trickling through a goddess statue as whispers or vocalizations from the goddess herself.<ref name=Totem/> Dewey-Hagborg saw a parallel between the "mystical and authoritative power of language in the ancient world and the force of power of technology today"<ref name="Totem">{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Totem|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GsTu3Iv1408|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=June 28, 2010}}</ref> and, with this piece, sought to explore how technology is used to shape public opinion and behavior.
Martha Schwendener, of ''[[The New York Times]]'', wrote that ''Totem'' showed promise, but, because of audio difficulties and its fragmented, randomly generated speech, the piece "failed to connect human speech, meaning, and technology in a profound fashion."<ref name="Schwendener, M.">{{cite news|last1=Schwendener|first1=Martha|title=Populism, Technology, and Interactivity|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/nyregion/at-grounds-for-sculpture-works-by-james-surls-and-daniel-henderson-review.html?_r=0|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=The New York Times|date=August 28, 2011}}</ref>
===''Stranger Visions''=== [[File:Stranger Visions-1.jpg|left|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' Portraits (2012)]] ''Stranger Visions'' (2012–2014) is a science-based, artistic exploration using DNA as a starting point for Dewey-Hagborg's lifelike, computer generated 3-D portraits.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Jenkins, M.">{{cite news|last1=Jenkins|first1=Mark|title=A 'Cyber' exhibit as timely as the news|work=Washington Post|date=September 18, 2013|page=E18}}</ref><ref name="Krulwich, R.">{{cite web|last1=Krulwich|first1=Robert|title=Artist plays detective: Can I reconstruct a face from a piece of hair?|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/krulwich/2013/06/28/196307915/artist-plays-detective-can-i-reconstruct-a-face-from-a-piece-of-hair|website=NPR|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=June 28, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Le Monde">{{cite news|title=Trafics optiques a l'heure numerique: a Creteil, l'exposition "Micro Macro" interroge notre perception du reel"|work=Le Monde|date=April 6, 2014}}</ref>
She began this project questioning how much information could be understood about a person using genetic detritus left behind by strangers in [[New York City]].<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Brodwin, E.">{{cite journal|last1=Brodwin|first1=Erin|title=New Generation of Bio-Hackers make DNA misbehave|journal=Newsweek Global|date=July 4, 2014|volume=162|issue=26|pages=1–7|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2014/07/04/new-generation-bio-hackers-make-dna-misbehave-256322.html|accessdate=August 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/> "I was really struck by this idea that the very things that make us human – hair, skin, saliva, and fingernails – become a real liability for us as we constantly shed them in public. Anyone could come along and mine them for information."<ref name="Wang, L."/> She hoped, by producing realistic sculptures of anonymous people using clues from their DNA, to spark a debate about the use or the potential misuse of DNA profiling, privacy, and genetic surveillance.<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wilson Center">{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions: The DNA You Leave Behind|url=http://www.wilsoncenter.org/event/stranger-visions-the-dna-you-leave-behind|website=Wilson Center|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=June 3, 2013}}</ref><ref name="C: International Contemporary Art">{{cite journal|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg Stranger Visions|journal=C: International Contemporary Art|date=Winter 2014|volume=120|page=57}}</ref><ref name=Passarello>{{cite news|last1=Passarello|first1=D|title=Dna smarriti, una seconda vita che si fa opera d'arte|work=Il Sole 24 Ore|date=March 17, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Stranger Visions-6.jpg|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' portrait "Sample 2" based on the DNA sample from a cigarette butt collected on Myrtle Avenue in New York City, N.Y.<ref name="Gambino, M.">{{cite web|last1=Gambino|first1=Megan|title=Creepy or Cool? Portraits Derived From the DNA in Hair and Gum Found in Public Places|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/creepy-or-cool-portraits-derived-from-the-dna-in-hair-and-gum-found-in-public-places-50266864/?no-ist|website=Smithsonian|accessdate=August 18, 2014|date=May 3, 2013}}</ref>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-4.jpg|thumb|Collection site for DNA Samples; Corner of Wilson Avenue and Stanhope Street in [[Bushwick, New York|Bushwick, Brooklyn, New York]].<ref name="Gambino, M."/>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-2.jpg|thumb|Gum collected, which, when analyzed by Dewey-Hagborg, revealed a male of Native American and South American descent with brown eyes.<ref name="Gambino, M."/>]] As part of her research for ''Stranger Visions'', Dewey-Hagborg took a three-week crash-course<ref name="Wang, L."/> in biotechnology at Genspace, a non-profit, community-based biotechnology laboratory in New York. She was astonished to learn how much an amateur biologist could learn about someone.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Wang, L.">{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=Linda|title=Guarding Our DNA: Art project exposes the vulnerability of the genetic material we unintentionally leave behind|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=June 24, 2013|volume=91|issue=25|page=33}}</ref><ref name="Pauwels, E.">{{cite news|last1=Pauwels|first1=Eleanore|title=Leave me your DNA ... and I'll 3-D print your face|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jun/01/dna-art-recreate-faces|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=The Guardian|date=June 1, 2013}}</ref>
She began the process of extracting DNA from the samples she collected. The extraction involves treating a hair sample, for example, with a gel that dissolves the hair, and a primer specifically developed to help locate characteristics like eye color or gender along the [[genome]].<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Gruber, B.">{{cite news|last1=Gruber|first1=Ben|title=Artist stirs privacy debate with portraits from DNA|url=https://www.reuters.com/video/2013/07/02/artist-stirs-privacy-debate-with-portrai?videoId=243713123|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=Reuters|date=July 2, 2013}}</ref> Dewey-Hagborg might repeat this process up to 40 times,<ref name="Andersen, K."/> looking for genetic variants influencing traits like eye color, hair color, and racial ancestry, in order to complete a portrait.<ref name="Aldous, P.">{{cite news|last1=Aldous|first1=Peter|title=Artwork highlights legal debate over 'abandoned' DNA|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn23677-artworks-highlight-legal-debate-over-abandoned-dna.html#.U-N6YUi9g7A|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=New Scientist|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref>
Once the DNA strands are extracted from the samples, Dewey-Hagborg then amplifies, or copies, specific regions of the genome, using a technique called [[Polymerase Chain Reaction]], or PCR, a process advanced by [[Kary Mullis]], a winner of the [[Nobel Prize]] in Chemistry (1993).<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wang, L."/> These amplified regions of the genome make it possible to identifying [[single nucleotide polymorphisms]], or SNPs (pronounced "snips"),<ref name=Passarello/> which contain variables in the base pairs that give clues to a person's individual genetic make up (e.g., whether or not a person's eyes might be blue, brown or green). These results are then sent for analysis to a company for sequencing. Dewey-Hagborg used [[23andMe]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/> a DNA analysis service, for ''Stranger Visions''. [[File:Dna-SNP.svg|left|thumb|Illustration of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs)]] [[File:Stranger Visions-5.jpeg|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' portrait "Sample 3" <ref>{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Portraits|url=http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/portraits.html|website=Heather Dewey-Hagborg|accessdate=August 18, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141003124410/http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/portraits.html|archivedate=October 3, 2014|df=}}</ref>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-3.jpg|thumb|Sample collected for ''Stranger Visions'' on Myrtle Avenue, [[Brooklyn, New York]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Samples|url=http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/samples.html|website=Heather Dewey-Hagborg|accessdate=August 18, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013095339/http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/samples.html|archivedate=October 13, 2014|df=}}</ref>]]
The genetic blueprint<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Gruber, B."/> she receives in return is a text file full of coded information identifying the unique positioning of the 4 [[nucleobase]]s [[adenine]], [[thymine]], [[cytosine]], and [[guanine]], or ATC and G, that make up the sections of the genome she is interested in.<ref name="Squires, A."/> This data is then entered into a customized computer program she wrote.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/> The program interprets the code and provides her with a list of traits, including propensity for obesity, eye color, hair color, hair curl, skin tone, freckles, and gender.<ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/> She then takes these traits, as many as 50, and enters them into a face-generating program to configure the 3-D portraits.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Wang, L."/> Her previous experience with facial recognition algorithms gave her the ability to repurpose an existing [[facial recognition system|facial recognition program]], from [[Basel]], Switzerland.<ref name="Walters, H.">{{cite web|last1=Walters|first1=Helen|title=A Portrait from a Single Hair: The Work of Heather-Dewey Hagborg|url=http://ideas.ted.com/2013/06/20/generating-a-sculpture-from-a-hair-the-work-of-heather-dewey-hagborg/|website=Ideas.Ted.Com|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=June 20, 2013}}</ref> She reworked the program to generate faces instead of just recognizing facial features.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> The resulting model changes facial dimensions (e.g., width of the nose and mouth) and characteristics with the genetic information it receives. Before making the final 3-D print,<ref name="Pauwels, E."/> Dewey-Hagborg generates several different versions of the face, finally choosing the one she finds most aesthetically pleasing.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Andersen, K.">{{cite web|last1=Andersen|first1=Kurt|title=Making Portraits out of DNA|url=http://www.studio360.org/story/267842-making-portraits-out-of-dna|website=Studio 360|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=February 8, 2013}}</ref>
Critics of Dewey-Hagborg's ''Stranger Visions'' question whether or not the work crosses ethical and legal boundaries.<ref name="Aldous, Peter">{{cite journal|last1=Aldous|first1=Peter|title=Who's looking through your discarded DNA?|journal=New Scientist|date=2013-06-15|volume=281|issue=2921|page=12}}</ref> They make a distinction between an artist's right to express societal concerns through artwork and the act of collecting personal, genetic information without informed consent.<ref name="Gruber, B."/> The fact that DNA samples are regularly "left behind" or abandoned does not mean those people have relinquished their interest in how that information is used.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name=Passarello/>
Some laws, like that of the [[Human Tissue Act of 2004]] in the United Kingdom, prohibit private individuals from collecting biological samples for DNA analysis.<ref name="Pauwels, E."/> What laws that exist to regulate the collection and use of DNA samples in the United States are not consistent among the states and rarely address the private sector.<ref name="Wilson Center"/> Only some states, like New York, outlaw most DNA testing without written consent.<ref name="Aldous, Peter"/> Others worry about the misuse of the information, fearing discrimination based on existing medical or mental health issues or a predisposition for disease-related illnesses or "unreasonable" searches of DNA evidence by law enforcement.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/><ref name=Passarello/><ref name="Andersen, K."/><ref name="Enserink, M.">{{cite journal|last1=Enserink|first1=Martin|title=Emerging Forensics Field May Hit Legal and Ethical Obstacles|journal=Science|date=February 18, 2011|volume=331|doi=10.1126/science.331.6019.840|pages=840|pmid=21330505}}<!--|accessdate=August 7, 2014--></ref> One scientist and one gallery, according to Dewey-Hagborg, turned down her proposal fearing the project would "cause a fright" among people.<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wang, L."/>
Other critics focus on the growing do-it-yourself or [[Do-it-yourself biology|biohacking]] movement. Supporters like Genspace's Ellen Jorgensen claim projects like ''Stranger Visions'' engage the public and make the new technology more accessible.<ref name="Krulwich, R."/> Detractors fear unintended or unexpected consequences from unregulated experiments conducted by D.I.Y. amateur biologists developed in non-traditional laboratory settings.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/>
Still others, including Daniel MacArthur, an assistant professor at [[Harvard Medical School]], [[John D. Hawks]], an anthropologist at the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]], Michelle N. Meyer, an academic fellow at the Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology & Bioethics at Harvard Medical School, and [[Arthur Caplan]], PhD, Director of the Division of Medical Ethics, N.Y.U., report that the technological capability to construct an accurate likeness of a human face based on DNA evidence is not currently available.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/>
Although it is possible to identify certain genetic markers linked to facial structures, scientists have yet to isolate all the genes and their variations needed to produce an accurate likeness with a computer simulation.<ref name=Passarello/> Meyer, who analyzed the data from Dewey-Hagborg's website concludes:
<blockquote>So far as I can tell, she's working with sex; ancestral groups that are usually very broad, and in any event only reflects half of the individual's DNA (from which she presumably guesses hair color and texture and bone structure); and a decent guess at eye color. There are hundreds of thousands (at least) of people who would fit these descriptions even if each of her phenotype predictions were accurate, and in many cases, one or more of the predictions are probably going to be wrong.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name=Passarello/></blockquote>
The environment, the probabilistic nature of interpreting the DNA data collected, and limitations of computer technology all influence the outcome.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Colanduno, D."/> She likens her work to that of a sketch artist.<ref name="Squires, A."/> At most, her portraits bear only a vague, family resemblance to the people whose genetic information was used as a foundation for the portraits.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/>
===''A Becoming Resemblance''=== In the summer of 2017 Dewey-Hagborg's collaborative exhibition with transgender activist [[Chelsea E. Manning]] opened at Fridman Gallery. The exhibition was an iteration of the artist's successful and controversial ''Stranger Visions'' project.<ref name="Kobler, J.">{{cite news|last1=Kobler|first1=Jason|title=Don't Give Your DNA to Giant Genetic Databases|work=Vice|date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In the case of ''A Becoming Resemblance'', Dewey-Hagborg created a series titled ''Radical Love'', 30 3-D printed portraits of Manning, based on cheek swabs and hair clippings that Manning sent her while incarcerated for leaking classified information to WikiLeaks. While all 30 portraits were based on Manning's DNA, their variances in skin color and features presents the malleability of DNA data. The installation demonstrated how much the human genome is up for interpretation once condensed and subjectively interpreted. "<ref name="Nevins, J.">{{cite news|last1=Nevins|first1=Jake|title=A Becoming Resemblance: artist creates portraits using Chelsea Manning's DNA.|work=The Guardian|date=August 3, 2017}}</ref> ''A Becoming Resemblance'' has since traveled to numerous institutions for exhibition, including The Transmedial in Berlin<ref name="Taylor, A.">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Alan|title=Photos of the Week: Super Blue Blood Moon, Starry Night, Stratofortress|work=The Atlantic|date=May 8, 2018}}</ref> ,Fridman Gallery,<ref>https://deweyhagborg.com/bio/</ref> MU Art Space in the Netherlands,<ref>http://www.mu.nl/en/exhibitions/heather-dewey-hagborg-genomic-intimacy</ref> and the 2018 Seattle Art Fair.<ref>https://seattleartfair.com/Projects-Talks/2018/Heather-Dewey-Hagborg-and-Chelsea-E-Manning-Probab.aspx</ref>
===Delaware=== [[File:Invisible-3.tif|thumb|''Invisible'' (2014)]] In 2013, Dewey-Hagborg was contacted by an assistant medical examiner in Delaware,<ref name="Dawsey, J"/> as a result of her work with ''Stranger Visions''. The project involved developing a portrait of an unidentified woman whose case has remained unsolved for 20 years. She agreed to be an adviser to assist with the case.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> Though the resulting portrait based on the unidentified woman's DNA could only be as accurate as existing technology allowed, leaving room for speculation, Dewey-Hagborg viewed working on the case as the only potential use for this type of face-generating technology.<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Herper, M."/> "If you can add anything at all to her description, if you can increase the possibility her loved ones may find her even one little bit I think it's worth it."<ref name="Herper, M."/> Critics of Dewey-Hagborg's involvement in the Delaware case express concern for what they call "D.I.Y. forensic science" and question the role of civilians in state investigations.<ref name="Pauwels, E."/>
===''Invisible''=== [[File:Invisible-1.jpg|thumb|''Invisible'' (2014)]] Dewey-Hagborg's work with ''Stranger Visions'' and interest in issues surrounding genetic surveillance lead to the development of two products whose purpose is to eliminate DNA traces. The first, ''Erase'', is a bleaching spray that cleans surfaces (e.g., cups, silverware) of DNA evidence. The second, ''Replace'', is a spray consisting of a blend of genes designed to introduce foreign DNA evidence to the surface, therefore masking any of the original DNA remaining in that area.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/> Dewey-Hagborg views these as a "citizens' defense against the looming DNA surveillance state."<ref name="Hartnett, K.">{{cite news|last1=Hartnett|first1=Kevin|title=How to cover your DNA trail|work=Boston Globe|date=May 11, 2014}}</ref>
==Additional exhibitions and events== Dewey-Hagborg's work has been exhibited at The Monitor Digital Festival in [[Guadalajara]], Mexico,<ref name="C: International Contemporary Art"/> [[MoMA PS1|PS1 MoMA, Long Island City, New York]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="C: International Contemporary Art"/> the [[New York Public Library]] in New York City, the [[Science Gallery]] at [[Trinity College Dublin|Trinity College Dublin, Ireland]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Science Gallery, Dublin">{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Sculpture, 2013: Heather Dewey-Hagborg|url=https://dublin.sciencegallery.com/growyourown/strangervisions|website=Science Gallery|accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref> the [[University of Technology|UTS Gallery]] in [[Sydney, Australia]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> the [[Jaaga|Jaaga Art and Technology Center]] in [[Bangalore|Bangalore, India]], the [[Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen|Museum Boijmans]] in [[Rotterdam, Netherlands]], and the [[Ars Electronica Center]] in [[Linz, Austria]].<ref name="Colanduno, D."/>

The '''Hubble European Space Agency Information Centre''' ('''HEIC''') is a science communication office, established at the [[Space Telescope - European Coordinating Facility]] (ST-ECF) in [[Munich]], [[Germany]] late in 1999. This initiative was taken so as to fulfil the NASA/ESA [[Hubble Space Telescope]] (HST) outreach and education tasks for the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA), as outlined in an agreement between [[NASA]] and [[ESA]].
Over the past few years HEIC has become a very distinguished communication office of experts using the newest software and techniques. The European Hubble office has produced large amounts of astronomical material suitable both for educational purposes and wider public consumption. HEIC provides a well-assorted archive that is publicly available on its web page.
The work is centred on the production of news and photo releases that highlight interesting Hubble science results and images. These are often European in origin, and so not only increase the awareness of ESA’s Hubble share (15%), but the contribution of European scientists to the observatory. Furthermore, the group produces video releases, innovative educational material, CD-ROMs, brochures, posters, as well as DVDs and museum information kiosks, and much more.
The Hubble Information Centre is headed by the science communication specialist [[Lars Lindberg Christensen]] and the lead graphic designer is [[Martin Kornmesser]].

'''Humanities in the United States''' refers to the study of [[humanities]] disciplines, such as literature, history, language, performing and visual arts or philosophy, in the [[United States|United States of America]]. Many American colleges and universities seek to provide a broad "[[liberal arts education]]", in which all [[college]] students to study the humanities in addition to their specific area of study. Prominent proponents of liberal arts in the United States have included [[Mortimer J. Adler]]Adler, Mortimer J.; "A Guidebook to Learning: For the Lifelong Pursuit of Wisdom" and [[E.D. Hirsch]]. A liberal arts focus is often coupled with curricular requirements; colleges including [[Saint Anselm College]] and [[Providence College]] have mandatory two-year [[core curricula]] in the humanities for their students. The 1980 United States Rockefeller Commission on the Humanities described the humanities in its report, ''The Humanities in American Life'':
Through the humanities we reflect on the fundamental question: What does it mean to be human? The humanities offer clues but never a complete answer. They reveal how people have tried to make moral, spiritual, and intellectual sense of a world in which irrationality, despair, loneliness, and death are as conspicuous as birth, friendship, hope, and reason.
==Conceptual validity== The very concept of the ‘humanities’ as a class or kind, distinct from the ’sciences’, has come under repeated attack in the twentieth century. [[Thomas Samuel Kuhn|T.S. Kuhn]]’s ''[[The Structure of Scientific Revolutions]]''[[Thomas Samuel Kuhn|Kuhn, Thomas]], ''[[The Structure of Scientific Revolutions]]'', The [[University of Chicago Press]], 1962 argued that the forces driving scientific progress often have less to do with objective inference from unbiased observation than with much more value-laden sociological and cultural factors. More recently, [[Richard Rorty]] has argued that the distinction between the sciences and the humanities is harmful to both pursuits, placing the former on an undeserved pedestal and condemning the latter to irrationality. Rorty’s position requires a wholesale rejection of such traditional philosophical distinctions as those between appearance and reality, subjective and objective, replacing them with what he endorses as a new ‘fuzziness’. This leads to a kind of pragmatism where "the oppositions between the humanities, the arts, and the sciences, might gradually fade away... In this situation, ‘the humanities’ would no longer think of themselves as such...."[[Richard Rorty|Rorty, Richard]], ''Science as Solidarity'', in ''Objectivity, Relativism and Truth: Philosophical Papers Volume I'', [[Cambridge University Press]], 1991 ==Modernism and postmodernism== In the United States, the late 20th century saw a challenge to the "elitism" of the humanities, which [[Edward Said]] has characterized as a "conservative philosophy of gentlemanly refinement, or sensibility." Such [[postmodernism|postmodernists]] argued that the humanities should go beyond the study of "[[dead white males]]" to include work by women and people of color, and without religious bias. The French philosopher [[Michel Foucault]] has been a very influential part of this movement, stating in ''The Order of Things'' that "we can study only individuals, not human nature." However some in the humanities believed that such changes could be detrimental; the result is said to be what [[E. D. Hirsch Jr.]] refers to as declining [[cultural literacy]].Kernan, Alvin, editor; ''What's Happened to the Humanities?'', [[Princeton University Press]], Princeton, New Jersey, 1997 ==National institutions== President [[Lyndon Johnson]] signed the [[National Foundation on the Arts and Humanities Act]] in 1965,[http://www.neh.gov/whoweare/overview.html www.neh.gov] creating the National Council on the Humanities, and funded the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] (NEH) in 1969. NEH is an independent grant-making agency of the United States government dedicated to supporting research, education, preservation, and public programs in the humanities (see [[Public humanities]]). NEH facilitated the creation of State Humanities Councils[http://www.neh.gov/whoweare/statecouncils.html www.neh.gov] in the 56 [[U.S. state]]s and [[Territories of the United States|territories]]. Each council operates independently, defining the "humanities" in relationship to the disciplines, subjects, and values valued in the regions they serve. Councils give grant funds to individuals, scholars, and nonprofit organizations dedicated to the humanities in their region. Councils also offer diverse programs and services that respond to the needs of their communities and according to their own definitions of the humanities. ==Career prospects== Criticism of the traditional humanities/liberal arts degree program has been leveled by critics who see them as both expensive and relatively "useless" in the modern American job market, where several years of specialized study is required in most job fields. According to a 2018 report by the [[Humanities Indicators]], unemployment rates for humanities majors were slightly higher and their earnings were slightly lower than the averages for college degree recipients with similar degree levels (though both were still substantially better than for those without a college degree). Their overall levels of satisfaction with their jobs and their lives, however, were essentially the same as graduates from other fields, with more than 85% of humanities graduates reporting they were satisfied with their jobs. As of 2015, approximately five million people employed in management and professional jobs had bachelor’s degrees in the humanities.{{Cite book|title=The State of the Humanities 2018: Graduates in the Workforce & Beyond|last=|first=|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|year=2018|isbn=|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=5-6, 12, 19}} ==See also== *[[Social science]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.nhc.rtp.nc.us/ National Humanities Center] *[http://neh.gov National Endowment for the Humanities] [[Category:Humanities|Humanities]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Institute for Computational Cosmology (ICC) | parent_organization = [[Durham University]] | location = [[Durham, England]] | mission = to advance fundamental knowledge in [[cosmology]] | key_people = [[Carlos Frenk]]
[[Shaun Cole]] | website = {{URL|icc.dur.ac.uk}} }}The '''Institute for Computational Cosmology (ICC)''' is a Research Institute{{cite web | title = Durham University Research Institutes | url = http://www.dur.ac.uk/research/institutes/ | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131216210910/https://www.dur.ac.uk/research/institutes/ | archivedate = 16 December 2013 | df = }} at [[Durham University]], [[England]]. It was founded in November 2002 as part of the Ogden Centre for Fundamental Physics, which also includes the Institute for Particle Physics Phenomenology (IPPP). The ICC's primary mission is to advance fundamental knowledge in [[Physical cosmology|cosmology]]. Topics of active research include: the nature of [[dark matter]] and [[dark energy]], the evolution of [[Large-scale structure of the universe|cosmic structure]], [[Galaxy formation|the formation of galaxies]], and the determination of [[Just Six Numbers#Martin Rees's Six Numbers|fundamental parameters]]. The current director of the ICC is [[Carlos Frenk]]; the deputy director is [[Shaun Cole]]. ICC researchers have played a central role{{Cite journal | bibcode = 1985ApJ...292..371D | title = The evolution of large-scale structure in a universe dominated by cold dark matter | last1 = Davis | first1 = M. | author1-link = Marc Davis (astronomer) | last2 = Efstathiou | author2-link = George Efstathiou | first2 = G. | last3 = Frenk | first3 = C. S. | author3-link = Carlos Frenk | last4 = White | first4 = S. D. M. | author4-link = Simon White | volume = 292 | date = 1985 | pages = 371 | journal = Astrophysical Journal | doi = 10.1086/163168 }}{{Cite journal | bibcode = 2000MNRAS.319..168C | title = Hierarchical galaxy formation | last1 = Cole | first1 = Shaun | last2 = Lacey | last3 = Baugh | last4 = Frenk | volume = 319 | date = 2000 | pages = 168 | journal = [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-8711.2000.03879.x | first2 = Cedric G. | first3 = Carlton M. | first4 = Carlos S.| arxiv = astro-ph/0007281 }}{{Citation | last = Dodelson | first = Scott | title = Review of astro-ph topcites | year = 2003 | url = http://www.slac.stanford.edu/spires/topcites/older/topcites/2003/eprints/astro-ph_review.shtml | accessdate = 6 September 2013 }} in the development of the standard model of cosmology, [[Lambda-CDM model]] (ΛCDM). Because of the vast scale of questions in cosmology, advances often require [[high performance computing|supercomputer]] [[N-body simulations|simulations]] in which a virtual Universe is allowed to evolve for [[Age of the universe|13.8 billion years]] from the [[Big Bang]] to the present day. The simulation is rerun with different ingredients or different physics, until it matches the [[Observational cosmology|observed Universe]]. This approach has required one of the most powerful supercomputers for academic research in the world, the “Cosmology Machine (COSMA)” as part of the [[DiRAC]] [[supercomputing]] consortium.Listed as 12th overall in the UK, 134th in the world by {{cite web | title = Top 500 supercomputer sites | date = June 2012 | url = http://www.top500.org/list/2012/06/?page=2 | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131102043526/http://www.top500.org/list/2012/06/?page=2 | archivedate = 2 November 2013 | df = }} == History == Durham University's extragalactic astronomy group was founded in the late 1970s, and secured in 1984-5 with the appointments of [[Carlos Frenk]], [[Richard Ellis (astronomer)|Richard Ellis]], and Tom Shanks. A group researching theoretical cosmology grew steadily during the 1980s and 1990s, mainly funded by the UK [[Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council]] (PPARC). A dedicated building for theoretical cosmology was then funded through private donations, principally from alumnus [[Peter Ogden]], and opened in 2002 by the Prime Minister, [[Tony Blair]].{{cite web|last=Barrat|first=Peter|title=Prime Minister Tony Blair Opens New Centre for Physics Research|url=http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=9567|publisher=PPARC|date=18 October 2002 | accessdate = 6 September 2013 }} The group has grown in these new facilities, and the ICC now hosts more than 60 researchers, including theoretical and observational cosmologists, as well as astroparticle physicists.{{Citation | title = ICC Personnel | url = http://icc.dur.ac.uk/index.php?content=Staff/Staff | accessdate = 6 September 2013 }} Although the ICC is strictly speaking a theoretical institute, theory and observations in cosmology are intimately interwoven. Uniquely amongst Durham University's Research Institutes, the ICC and IPPP are structurally integrated within an academic and teaching department, [[Durham University Department of Physics|Physics]]. The physics department as a whole was awarded grade 5A in the 2001 [[Research Assessment Exercise]]{{cite web | title = Research Assessment Exercise 2001 | publisher = Higher Education Funding Council for England | url = http://www.rae.ac.uk/2001/ | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131003145917/http://www.rae.ac.uk/2001/ | archivedate = 3 October 2013 | df = }} (RAE) carried out by the UK government, with the international excellence of research in Astronomy and Particle Physics specifically highlighted. The department's research in Space Science and Astrophysics was rated as number one in Europe and fourth in the world by Thomson Reuters from its Essential Science Indicators (1998–2008). {{Citation | title = Institutional rankings in space sciences | newspaper = Times Higher Education | date = 28 August 2008 | url = http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=26&storycode=403363 | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120729135121/http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=26&storycode=403363 | archivedate = 29 July 2012 | df = }} == High Performance Computing == The ICC's highest resolution simulations of the evolution of the Universe are performed on the Cosmology Machine (COSMA).{{cite web|url=http://icc.dur.ac.uk/index.php?content=Computing/Cosma|title=Institute for Computational Cosmology Durham University - PhD and postgraduate research in astronomy, astrophysics and cosmology|website=icc.dur.ac.uk}} COSMA-5 was installed in October 2012, {{cite news | last = Curtis | first = Sophie | title = Durham University upgrades supercomputer for cosmology research | publisher = Techworld | date = 8 May 2013 | url = http://news.techworld.com/data-centre/3446232/durham-university-upgrades-supercomputer-for-cosmology-research/ | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130621015113/http://news.techworld.com/data-centre/3446232/durham-university-upgrades-supercomputer-for-cosmology-research/ | archivedate = 21 June 2013 | df = }} as a hub of the UK national [[DiRAC|Distributed Research utilitising Advanced Computing (DiRAC)]] consortium.{{cite web |url=http://www.stfc.ac.uk/1263.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620074339/http://www.stfc.ac.uk/1263.aspx |archivedate=2013-06-20 |df= }} COSMA-5 includes 6720 2.6 GHz Intel Sandy Bridge [[Central processing unit]] (CPU) cores, 53,760 GByte of RAM, and 2.4PByte of data storage; it is one of the most powerful supercomputers in the world. The ICC acts as one of the two main nodes of the international [[Virgo Consortium]] for [[N-body simulations|cosmological supercomputer simulations]]. == Visualisations of cosmological simulations == A founding goal of the ICC is to "stimulate young people to aspire to be the scientists of tomorrow". {{Citation | title = 10 years of science outreach | journal = Dialogue | volume = 23 | pages = 10–11 | date = May–June 2012 | url = http://issuu.com/communicationsoffice/docs/dialogue_issue_23?e=2156517/2206854 | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160315031648/https://issuu.com/communicationsoffice/docs/dialogue_issue_23?e=2156517%2F2206854 | archivedate = 15 March 2016 | df = }}{{cite web | last = Edwards | first = Pete | title = From Higgs to Hubble (and some of the stuff in-between) | url = http://www.dur.ac.uk/physics.outreach/ | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130803005349/http://www.dur.ac.uk/physics.outreach/ | archivedate = 3 August 2013 | df = }} A full-time outreach officer is employed to develop teaching materials that draw upon current research and coordinate a [http://www.dur.ac.uk/physics/outreach/ programme of activities] in schools across the North East of England. The ICC's 3D short movie "Cosmic Origins",{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/OurCosmicOrigins|title=OurCosmicOrigins|website=YouTube|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160731105010/https://www.youtube.com/user/OurCosmicOrigins|archivedate=2016-07-31|df=}} which combines sequences of real astronomical data and supercomputer simulations,{{Citation | last = Holliman | first = Nick | author2 = Baugh, Carlton | author3 = Frenk, Carlos | author4 = Jenkins, Adrian | author5 = Froner, Barbara | author6 = Hassaine, Djamel | author7 = Helly, John | author8 = Metcalfe, Nigel | author9 = Okamoto, Takashi | title = Cosmic cookery: making a stereoscopic 3D animated movie | journal = Proc. SPIE | volume = 6055 | date = 27 January 2006 | url = http://proceedings.spiedigitallibrary.org/proceeding.aspx?articleid=727723 | doi = 10.1117/12.646644 | series = Stereoscopic Displays and Virtual Reality Systems XIII | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150105175735/http://proceedings.spiedigitallibrary.org/proceeding.aspx?articleid=727723 | archivedate = 5 January 2015 | df = }} won first prize for best [[3D film|stereoscopic movie]] at Stereoscopic Displays and Applications XXI.{{cite web | title = Stereoscopic Displays and Applications, 3D Theater Session | publisher = IS&T and SPIE | date = 2010 | url = http://www.stereoscopic.org/3dcinema/#2010 | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130916144113/http://www.stereoscopic.org/3dcinema/#2010 | archivedate = 16 September 2013 | df = }}{{cite news | title = Durham movie leaves Disney standing | newspaper = Durham Times | publisher = Newsquest | date = 30 January 2010 | url = http://www.durhamtimes.co.uk/news/4880368.Durham_movie_leaves_Disney_standing/ | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150105170538/http://www.durhamtimes.co.uk/news/4880368.Durham_movie_leaves_Disney_standing/ | archivedate = 5 January 2015 | df = }} The movie, and its sequel "Cosmic Origins 2" provided the core [[Edutainment|entertainment]] of a touring public exhibition that visited the [[Royal Society]]’s Summer Science Exhibitions{{cite web |url=http://royalsociety.org/summer-science/ |title=Royal Society|accessdate=2013-08-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810095743/http://royalsociety.org/summer-science/ |archivedate=2013-08-10 |df= }} 2009, 2010 and 2013, See Further{{cite web|url=http://seefurtherfestival.org/|title=Welcome to See Further: The Festival of Science + Arts - See Further Festival 2010|date=11 April 2014|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140411033519/http://seefurtherfestival.org/|archivedate=11 April 2014|df=}} 2010, the British Science Festival 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.britishscienceassociation.org/british-science-festival|title=British Science Festival|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130828001955/http://www.britishscienceassociation.org/british-science-festival|archivedate=2013-08-28|df=}} and Thailand's National Science and Technology Fair 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.pico.com/the-national-science-and-technology-fair/ |title=National Science and Technology Fair |accessdate=2013-08-29 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130828004018/http://www.pico.com/the-national-science-and-technology-fair/ |archivedate=2013-08-28 |df= }}{{cite news | author = British Council | title = 'Dark matter' holds key to the origins of the universe | date = 14 August 2013 | url = http://blog.britishcouncil.org/2013/08/14/dark-matter-holds-key-to-the-origins-of-the-universe/ | accessdate = 6 September 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130826174732/http://blog.britishcouncil.org/2013/08/14/dark-matter-holds-key-to-the-origins-of-the-universe/ | archivedate = 26 August 2013 | df = }} == References == {{reflist|35em}} {{Durham University}} [[Category:Astronomy institutes and departments]] [[Category:Research institutes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Astronomy in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in England]]

{{more footnotes|date=February 2008}} {{sexual orientation}}{{LGBT sidebar}}
'''Latent homosexuality''' is an [[erotic]] attraction toward members of the same sex that is not [[conscious]]ly experienced or expressed in overt action. This may mean a [[closeted|hidden]] inclination or potential for [[bi-curious|interest]] in [[homosexual]] relationships, which is either suppressed or not recognized, and which has not yet been explored, or may never be explored.
The term was originally proposed by [[Sigmund Freud]]. Some argue that the latent homosexuality is a potentially [[iatrogenesis|iatrogenic]] effect (that is, it is not present until suggested by a therapist).{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} Others argue that the term ''latent'' is not truly applicable in the case of homosexual urges, since they are often not in the unconscious or unexpressed category, but rather exist in the conscious mind and are (often violently) [[Psychological repression|repressed]] on a conscious level.
==Links to homophobia== A [[theory]] that [[homophobia]] is a result of latent homosexuality was put forth in the late 20th century. A 1996 study conducted at the [[University of Georgia]] by Henry Adams, Lester Wright Jr., and Bethany Lohr<ref name=homophobiastudy>{{Cite journal|url=http://my.psychologytoday.com/files/u47/Henry_et_al.pdf|pmid=8772014|year=1996|last1=Adams|first1=HE|last2=Wright Jr|first2=LW|last3=Lohr|first3=BA|title=Is homophobia associated with homosexual arousal?|volume=105|issue=3|pages=440–5|journal=Journal of Abnormal Psychology|doi=10.1037/0021-843X.105.3.440}}</ref> indicates that a number of homophobic males exhibit latent homosexuality. The research was done on 64 heterosexual men, 35 of whom exhibited homophobic traits and 29 who did not. They were assigned to groups on the basis of their scores on the Index of Homophobia (W. W. Hudson & W. A. Ricketts, 1980). The groups did not differ in aggression.<ref name=homophobiastudy />
Three tests were conducted using [[penile plethysmography]]. While there was no difference in response when the men were exposed to [[heterosexual]] and [[lesbian]] [[pornography]], there was a major difference in response when the men were exposed to male homosexual pornography.
The researchers reported that 24% of the non-homophobic men showed some degree of [[tumescence]] in response to the male homosexual video, compared to 54% of the subjects who scored high on the homophobia scale. In addition, 66% of the non-homophobic group showed no significant increases in [[tumescence]] after this video, but only 20% of the homophobic men failed to display any arousal. Additionally, when the participants rated their degree of sexual arousal later, the homophobic men significantly underestimated their degree of arousal by the male homosexual video.
The results of this study indicate that individuals who score in the homophobic range and admit negative affect toward homosexuality demonstrate significant sexual arousal to male homosexual erotic stimuli.
A possible explanation is found in various psychoanalytic theories, which have generally explained homophobia as a threat to an individual's own homosexual impulses causing repression, denial, or reaction formation (or all three; West, 1977). Generally, these varied explanations conceive of homophobia as one type of latent homosexuality where persons either are unaware of or deny their homosexual urges.<ref name=homophobiastudy />
Another explanation of these data is found in Barlow, Sakheim, and Beck's (1983) theory of the role of anxiety and attention in sexual responding. It is possible that viewing homosexual stimuli causes negative emotions such as anxiety in homophobic men but not in nonhomophobic men. Because anxiety has been shown to enhance arousal and erection, this theory would predict increases in erection in homophobic men.<ref name=homophobiastudy />
[[Reparative therapy]] advocates {{who|date=May 2013}} disagree that the homophobic males were stimulated by genuine latent homosexuality, claiming that the stimulation arose from negative emotions such as anxiety.
==Links to environment== Living in a homophobic [[culture]], not being exposed to homosexuality, and being surrounded by members of both genders may encourage latent homosexuality.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} Conversely, [[Situational sexual behavior|situational homosexuality]] may be due to exposure to a single-gender environment, such as a [[single-sex education|single-sex school]], prison, or military service.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}}
==In fiction== In [[Kingsley Amis]]' 1966 book, ''[[The Anti-Death League]]'' the main character is introduced while resisting treatment for repressed homosexuality – which a doctor believes that he has – despite the man being openly homosexual.
Latent homosexual themes were a common theme of science fiction films of the 1950s.<ref name="Geraghty2009">{{cite book |author=Lincoln Geraghty |title=American Science Fiction Film and Television |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WkILrUVObWQC&pg=PT23 |date=1 October 2009 |publisher=[[Berg Publishers|Berg]] |isbn=978-0-85785-076-8 |page=23}}</ref>
In the 1999 film ''[[American Beauty (1999 film)|American Beauty]]'' the character Colonel Fitts ([[Chris Cooper]]) is depicted as being a latent homosexual. Throughout the film, Fitts makes several statements that are narrow-minded and [[homophobic]], and it disturbs the colonel that his son Ricky might be homosexual. However, towards the end of the film, it is revealed that Fitts himself has sexual feelings towards men when he approaches his neighbor Lester Burnham ([[Kevin Spacey]]) and kisses him, but Lester rejects Col. Fitts, and this greatly humiliates him.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0169547/?ref_=fn_tt_tt_1 |series=film title |title=American Beauty |website=IMDb.com}}</ref>

{{for|the racehorse|Legal Case}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2007}} A '''legal case''' is a dispute between opposing parties resolved by a [[court]], or by some equivalent legal process. A legal case may be either [[Civil law (common law)|civil]] or [[criminal law]]. In each legal case there is an [[Plaintiff|accuser]] and one or more [[defendant]]s.
==Civil case== A civil case, more commonly known as a [[lawsuit]] or [[Controversy (law)|controversy]], begins when a [[plaintiff]] [[file (legal)|files]] a document called a [[complaint]] with a court, informing the court of the wrong that the plaintiff has allegedly suffered because of the [[defendant]], and requesting a [[judicial remedy|remedy]]. The remedy sought may be money, an [[injunction]], which requires the defendant to perform or refrain from performing some action, or a [[declaratory judgment]], which determines that the plaintiff has certain legal rights. The remedy will be prescribed by the court if the plaintiff wins the case. A civil case can also be arbitrated through [[arbitration]], which may result in a faster settlement, with lower costs, than could be obtained by going through a trial.
The plaintiff must make a genuine effort to inform the defendant of the case through [[service of process]], by which the plaintiff delivers to the defendant the same documents that the plaintiff filed with the court.
At any point during the case, the parties can agree to a [[settlement (law)|settlement]], which will end the case, although in some circumstances, such as in [[class action]]s, a settlement requires court approval in order to be binding.
===Family case=== Cases involving separation including asset division, support (a.k.a. maintenance or alimony), and matters related to children are handled differently in different jurisdictions. Often, the court's procedure for dealing with family cases is very similar to that of a civil case (it requires service and disclosure, and will issue judgments).
Divorce and separation from a spouse is one of the most stressful situations, as rated by the [[Holmes and Rahe stress scale#Adults|Holmes and Rahe Stress Scale]], and so family proceedings are increasingly being "divorced" from the often very formal and impersonal process of civil proceedings, and given special treatment.
==Criminal case== {{Main article|Criminal case}} [[File:CanadianCriminalCases.jpg|thumb|Canadian criminal cases]] A [[criminal case]], in [[common law (legal system)|common law]] jurisdictions, begins when a person suspected of a crime is [[indictment|indicted]] by a grand jury or otherwise charged with the offense by a government official called a [[prosecutor]] or [[district attorney]].
A criminal case may in some jurisdictions be settled before a [[Trial (law)|trial]] through a [[plea bargain]]. Typically, in a plea bargain, the defendant agrees to plead guilty to a lesser charge than that which was originally brought by the grand jury or prosecuter. A defendant who goes to trial risks greater penalties than would normally be imposed through a plea bargain.
==Common elements== Legal cases, whether criminal or civil, are premised on the idea that a dispute will be fairly resolved when a [[legal procedure]] exists by which the dispute can be brought to a factfinder not otherwise involved in the case, who can evaluate [[evidence (law)|evidence]] to determine the truth with respect to claims of guilt, innocence, liability, or lack of fault. Details of the procedure may depend on both the kind of case and the kind of system in which the case is brought - whether, for example, it is an [[inquisitorial system]] or a solo
===Designation and citation=== <!--Linked from [[Tochigi patricide case]]--> {{main|Case citation}} In most systems, the governing body responsible for overseeing the courts assigns a unique number/letter combination or similar designation to each case in order to track the various disputes that are or have been before it. The outcome of the case is recorded, and can later be reviewed by obtaining a copy of the documents associated with the designation previously assigned to the case.
However, it is often more convenient to refer to cases{{spaced ndash}}particularly landmark and other notable cases{{spaced ndash}}by a title of the form ''Claimant [[wikt:v.|v]] Defendant'' (e.g. ''[[Arkell v Pressdram]]''). Where a legal proceeding does not have formally designated adverse parties, a form such as ''[[In re]]'', ''Re'' or ''In the matter of'' is used (e.g. ''[[In re Gault]]'').<ref>{{cite book |title=The Oxford University Standard for Citation of Legal Authorities |url=http://www.law.ox.ac.uk/publications/oscola.php |publisher=Hart Publishers |edition=4 |year=2012 |isbn=9781849463676}}</ref> The "v" separating the parties is an abbreviation of the Latin [[wikt:versus|versus]], but, when spoken in [[Commonwealth countries]], it is normally rendered as "[[wikt:and|and]]" or "[[wikt:against|against]]" (as in, for example, [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[Jarndyce and Jarndyce]]''). Where it is considered necessary to protect the anonymity of a [[natural person]], some cases may have one or both parties replaced by a standard pseudonym ([[John Doe|Jane Roe]] in ''[[Roe v. Wade]]'') or by an initial (''[[D v D]]''). In titles such as ''[[R v Adams]]'', however, the initial "R" is usually an abbreviation for the Latin [[King|Rex]] or [[Queen regnant|Regina]], i.e. for [[the Crown]]. (For an explanation of other terms that may appear in case titles, see the [[Glossary of legal terms]].)
