[[Gammon India]] and Construtora Cidade (Construction)
[[Wacker Neuson]] (Wind Tunnel Study)
[[Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee|IIT Roorkee]] (Seismic Design) |design= [[Cantilever spar cable-stayed bridge]] | architect = Ratan J. Batliboi - Architects Pvt Ltd, Mumbai (Architectural Advisor) |mainspan= {{convert|251|m|ft|0}} |length= {{convert|675 |m|ft|0}} |height= {{convert|165 |m|ft|0}} |clearance= |coordinates = {{coord|28.7053|77.2340|display=inline,title}} |map_type = India Delhi |below= |traffic= |material=Steel and Concrete |begin= 2004 |open= 4 November 2018 by Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal, {{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/new-deadline-signature-bridge-style-/articleshow/64847310.cms|title=New deadline, Signature Bridge style...|date= 4 July 2018| accessdate=7 July 2018|publisher= Times of India}} |closed= |toll= |label = |label_size = |alt = |background = |mark = |marksize = |float = |width = {{convert|35.2 |m|ft|0}} }} The '''Signature Bridge''' is a [[Cantilever spar cable-stayed bridge|cantilever spar cable-stayed bridge]] which spans the [[Yamuna]] river at Wazirabad section, connecting [[Wazirabad, Delhi|Wazirabad]] to [[East Delhi]].{{cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/delhi-news/signature-bridge-to-be-ready-by-october-arvind-kejriwal-1878987|title= Signature Bridge To Be Ready By October: Arvind Kejriwal|date= 6 July 2018| accessdate=6 July 2018|publisher= www.ndtv.com}} It is India's first asymmetrical [[cable-stayed bridge]]. The [[Tower#Transportation support|pylon]] of the Signature bridge is the tallest structure in Delhi and is double the height of [[Qutb Minar]] with its 154-metre high viewing box, which acts as selfie points for visitors.{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi-news/154-metre-high-viewing-box-selfie-points-delhi-s-signature-bridge-opens-tomorrow/story-ss5rUlwFk5PI7Tkz2SV2AL.html|title=154-metre high viewing box, selfie points: Delhi’s Signature Bridge opens today}} It shortens the travel time between north and northeast Delhi.{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/as-signature-bridge-opens-rush-to-ease-on-ring-road-and-nh-9/articleshow/66493331.cms?utm_source=twitter.com&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=TOIDesktop|title=As Delhi's Signature Bridge opens, rush to ease on Ring Road and National Highway-9}} ==Background== [[File:Wazirabad bridge on sahibi river.jpg|thumb|left|The old wazirabad bridge]] In 1997, 28 school students died in an accident on the narrow Wazirabad bridge. Since then, the Delhi government had plans to build another parallel wide bridge nearby to alleviate traffic congestions. By the end of 1998, the [[Government of Delhi|Delhi government]] finalised the draft plan for this bridge. The bridge was inaugurated on 4 November 2018 by the Chief Minister of Delhi [[Arvind Kejriwal]] with the aim to ease the burgeoning traffic congestion on the existing [[Wazirabad]] bridge.{{cite news |title=Delhi's Signature Bridge To Have Selfie Spots, Glass Viewing Deck |url=https://www.ndtv.com/delhi-news/delhi-signature-bridge-opens-to-public-on-monday-heres-what-it-offers-1942195 |accessdate=4 November 2018 |publisher=NDTV |date=3 November 2018}} ==History== By the end of 1998, the Delhi government finalized the draft plan made by Divyansh Sharma for the construction of the bridge. However, the construction of the bridge was stuck due to multiple reasons - lack of manpower and financial difficulties, being the major reason. When the project started, its cost was estimated to be ₹1,100 crore. Now it has surpassed ₹1,875 crores.{{cite news|title= More funds for Signature Bridge may help it meet latest dead|url= https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/more-funds-for-signature-bridge-may-help-it-meet-latest-deadline/articleshow/64890739.cms|date= 7 July 2018| accessdate= 7 July 2018 |publisher=Times of India }}{{cite news|url=http://www.theweekendleader.com/Headlines/13516/delhi-government-clears-signature-bridge-project.html|title=Delhi government clears signature bridge project |date= 6 July 2018| accessdate=7 July 2018|publisher=www.theweekendleader.com}} The [[Government of Delhi|Delhi government]] was tight handed and it was very difficult for it to shell out the extra rising budget. ₹1,244 crores of rupees have been sanctioned recently through PBDB. The work had started in full swing in 2004 on the bridge. A fresh deadline of end 2016 was set in 2013. Since then half a dozen times, deadlines have been missed and fresh deadlines set. Finally, the bridge was inaugurated in November 2018.{{cite news|url=https://kolkata24x7.com/delhi-may-get-indias-first-asymmetrical-cable-stayed-bridge-by-october-will-decongest-wazirabad-bridge.html|title= নজির গড়ে দেশের বুকে তৈরি হচ্ছে প্রথম ‘অ্যাসমিট্রিক্যাল’ ব্রিজ|date= 6 July 2018| accessdate=6 July 2018|publisher= kolkata24x7.com}} ==Details== The bridge is a [[Cantilever spar cable-stayed bridge]], a type of [[Cable-stayed bridge]] and in which cables were in a combination of radial and semi-harp arrangement, in which cables are spaced apart on the pylon, like the harp design, but connect to one point or a number of closely spaced points on the deck.{{cite book|author1=T.K. Bandyopadhyay|author2=Alok Baishya|editor1=P. Dayaratnam|editor2=G.P. Garg|editor3=G.V. Ratnam|editor4=R.N. Raghavan|title=International Conference on Suspension, Cable Supported, and Cable Stayed Bridges: November 19–21, 1999, Hyderabad|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pb67nkDk4FMC&pg=PA282|year=2000|publisher=Universities Press (India)|isbn=978-81-7371-271-5|pages=282, 373}} The dynamically shaped pylon consists of 2 inclined columns, which are rigidly connected to the driving lanes and bend mid-way. The upper portion of the pylon anchors the back-stay cables as well as the main-span cables and the self-weight of the pylon balances out the self-weight of the super structure through the eccentric location of its center of gravity with respect to the pivot point of the pylon footing, reducing the load on back-stay cables which are fewer in numbers converged from the main-span cables. The bridge is 675 meters long and 35.2 meters wide.{{cite news|url=https://www.sbp.de/en/project/yamuna-bridge-at-wazirabad-1/|title=Yamuna Bridge at Wazirabad |date = 6 July 2018| accessdate= }} Built on the Yamuna river, this bridge connects east Delhi to Wazirabad. When the bridge will be opened for general public, the traffic pressure on the narrow and dilapidated old Wazirabad Bridge will ease out significantly.{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi-news/signature-bridge-a-ray-of-hope-over-the-yamuna/story-qRgxQglOnbDv7acscTRKRO.html|title=Signature Bridge: A ray of hope over the Yamuna}} Just like the [[Eiffel Tower]] in [[France]], Signature Bridge will also have the facility to transport tourists on top of the main pillar, which is 154 m high, from where distant views of North Delhi can be seen.{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi-news/delhi-s-eiffel-tower-signature-bridge-over-yamuna-inaugurated/story-e0kdeOLcKSoCH18mu6OIlN.html|title=‘Delhi’s Eiffel Tower’: Signature Bridge inaugurated, opens to public tomorrow}} * Structural Design Firm: [[Schlaich Bergermann Partner]] * Contractor: Joint Venture [[Gammon India]]{{cite journal |last1=Gammon |title=Cover Story: [[File:Fred Thompson in spin room.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Former U.S. Senator and debate participant [[Fred Thompson]] addresses reporters in the spin room following a [[Republican Party presidential debates, 2008#December 9.2C 2007 - Miami.2C Florida|Republican presidential primary debate]] in 2007.]]
A '''spin room''', also known as '''spin row'''<ref>{{cite web|last=Reaves|first=Jessica|title=As the Spin Room Turns|url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,56609,00.html|work=Time|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=4 October 2000}}</ref> or '''spin alley''',<ref>{{cite news|last=Mathes|first=Michael|title=Spin Alley: getting out the message over debate din|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i-iFl3wU6MNVZvub-ufTpJcw7jig|accessdate=23 October 2012|newspaper=Agence France-Presse|date=23 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="TribCritic">{{cite web|last=Rosenthal|first=Phil|title=Spin room coverage out of control|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-09-26/business/0809250750_1_post-debate-spin-operatives|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=26 September 2008}}</ref> is an area in which [[reporter]]s can speak with [[debate]] participants and/or their representatives after a debate. The name refers to the fact that the participants will attempt to "[[spin (public relations)|spin]]" or influence the perception of the debate among the assembled reporters. The benefit for reporters is that they quickly get in-person interviews with debaters or their representatives, complete with audio, video and photos. For a [[United States presidential election debates|U.S. presidential debate]], the number of reporters in the spin room can number into the thousands.<ref name="TwitterSpin">{{cite web|last=Calderone|first=Michael|title=For 2012 Presidential Debates, Campaigns Speed Up The Spin|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/01/2012-presidential-debates-spin-room_n_1929185.html|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=1 October 2012}}</ref>
==History== The earliest known spin room was set up by the [[political campaign|campaign]] of U.S. president [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1984. In a hotel banquet room, campaign officials spoke on the record with [[talking point]]s playing up their own candidate's debate performance and minimizing opponent [[Walter Mondale]]'s success, despite many observers believing Mondale had just won. This operation was dubbed the "spin patrol."<ref>{{cite news|last=Santini|first=Maureen|title='Spin patrol' spins out|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=toNGAAAAIBAJ&pg=2229,1288893|accessdate=18 October 2012|newspaper=The Evening News|date=13 October 1984|agency=The Associated Press|location=Newburgh-Beacon, New York}}</ref>
==Operation== A spin room may also be active before a debate.<ref>{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Zeke|title=Before The Spin Room, Campaigns Pre-Wash The Press|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/zekejmiller/before-the-spin-room-campaigns-pre-wash-the-press|work=BuzzFeed|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=17 October 2012}}</ref> A common form of pre-debate spin is for each side to try to raise expectations for the opposing debater and lower expectations for their own team, a pursuit known as playing the [[expectations game]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=Leigh Ann|title=What's behind the debate expectations game?|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-250_162-57529085/whats-behind-the-debate-expectations-game/|work=CBS News|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=10 October 2012}}</ref>
==Criticism== Some observers have criticized the overt nature of the [[media manipulation]] in spin rooms, and the media's willing participation in it.<ref name="TribCritic"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Jay|title=Raze Spin Alley, That Strange Creation of the Press|url=http://archive.pressthink.org/2003/11/22/spin_alley.html|work=PressThink|accessdate=23 October 2012|date=22 November 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lanson|first=Jerry|title=The spin room - oily engine of the political meat grinder|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/1212/p11s01-coop.htm|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=12 December 2003}}</ref> Defenders have said reporters know it's scripted and aren't persuaded by the spin, but rather, they use the talking points to analyze candidates' strategies.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hardman|first1=Isabel|title=A (partial) defence of the spin room|url=http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/2015/04/a-partial-defence-of-the-spin-room/|website=The Spectator|accessdate=6 August 2015|date=30 April 2015}}</ref> Spin rooms can occasionally include moments of candor, such as when presidential candidate [[Rick Perry]] admitted that he had "stepped in it" during a debate response that became known as his [[Rick Perry presidential campaign, 2012#November 2011: "Oops" moment and continued struggles|"oops" moment]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Perry in spin room explains flub: "I stepped in it" (with video)|url=http://blogs.star-telegram.com/politex/2011/11/perry-in-spin-room-explains-flub-i-stepped-in-it-with-video.html|website=PoliTex|accessdate=6 August 2015|date=9 November 2011}}</ref>
Spin rooms have also been portrayed as outdated in an era of instant online reaction from all quarters before a debate is even over.<ref name="TwitterSpin"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Gaudin|first=Sharon|title=Twitter becomes new debate spin room|url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9232060/Twitter_becomes_new_debate_spin_room|work=Computer World|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=4 October 2012}}</ref> [[Focus group]]s and instant post-debate "snap [[opinion poll|polls]]" attempt to provide a more scientific method than spin rooms in determining who has won a debate.<ref>{{cite web|title=US presidential debate: Early polls give Barack Obama slender victory|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/uselection2008/presidentialdebates/3092194/US-presidential-debate-Early-polls-give-Barack-Obama-slender-victory.html|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=15 October 2015|date=27 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Clegg Beats Brown, Cameron in U.K. TV Debate, Polls Show|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-04-15/clegg-wins-top-mark-in-u-k-debate-polls-as-brown-cameron-stay-deadlocked.html|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=9 November 2012|date=16 April 2010}}</ref>

{{italic title}} '''''The Automatic Message''''' (1933) (''Le Message Automatique'') was one of [[André Breton]]'s significant theoretical works about automatism. The essay was first published in the magazine ''[[Minotaure]]'', No. 3-4, (Paris) 1933.
In 1997 it became the title of a compilation of [[surrealism|surrealist]] writing of [[André Breton]], [[Paul Éluard]] and [[Philippe Soupault]], amongst others. The book includes two vital “automatic” texts of surrealism.
Breton’s prefatory essay ''The Automatic Message'' relates the technique to the underlying concepts and aesthetic of surrealism.
''[[Les Champs Magnétiques|The Magnetic Fields (Les Champs Magnétiques)]]'' (1919) by Breton and Soupault, was the first work of literary surrealism and one of the foundations of modern European thought and writing. ''The Automatic Message'' contains the authorised translation by the poet [[David Gascoyne]], himself a member of the group, and a friend of both authors.
''The Immaculate Conception'' (1930) traces the interior and exterior life of man from ''Conception'' and ''Intra-Uterine Life'' to ''Death and The Original Judgement'', and includes a section with a series of “simulations” of various types of mental instability.
==Literature==
André Breton, ''The Automatic Message''. In: ''The Message. Art and Occultism''. Ed. by Claudia Dichter, Hans Günter Golinski, Michael Krajewski, Zander. Walther König: Cologne 2007, p. 33-55, {{ISBN|978-3-86560-342-5}}. (singular illustrated translation of Breton's Essay)

'''William M. Schniedewind''' (born 1962, [[New York City]])<ref>''Directory of American Scholars: Foreign languages, linguistics and philology'' (The Gale Group, 1999; {{ISBN|0787631647}}), p. 187.</ref> holds the Kershaw Chair of Ancient Eastern Mediterranean Studies and is a Professor of [[Bible|Biblical Studies]] and [[Semitic languages|Northwest Semitic Languages]] at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]].<ref name=ucla />

He has a B.A. in Religion from [[George Fox University]] in [[Newberg, Oregon]], an M.A. in Historical Geography of Ancient Israel, from [[Jerusalem University College]], and an M.A. and Ph.D. in Near Eastern and Judaic Studies, from [[Brandeis University]].<ref name=ucla />

Schniedewind serves on the steering committees for both the [http://www.humnet.ucla.edu/humnet/religion/home.html Center for the Study of Religion] and the Center for Jewish Studies at UCLA.<ref name=ucla>{{cite web |  title = William M. Schniedewind, Faculty Page, UCLA NELC
| url = http://www.nelc.ucla.edu/Faculty/Schniedewind.htm|publisher=[[UCLA]]}}</ref>  He serves as network editor for the Dead Sea Scrolls & Second Temple Judaism section of [http://www.cssr.org/ Religious Studies Review].  He serves on the editorial boards for the ''Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research, the Journal of Biblical Literature, and Tel Aviv''. He was a trustee and the secretary of the Albright Institute of Archaeological Research.

An article in [[The Christian Century]]  refers to Schniedewind as having demonstrated in his book ''How the Bible Became a Book'' his knowledge of the archaeology of ancient Israel, the history of the Hebrew language, and the development of historical literature based on the [[Bible]].<ref>Carr;, David ''The Christian Century'', Vol. 121, August 24, 2004.</ref>

Schniedewind is listed in the 2007 ''Distinguished Lecturer Series Speaker Biographies'' in the Dead Sea Scroll exhibition at the [[San Diego Natural History Museum]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sdnhm.org/scrolls/speakers/index.html|title=Distinguished Lecturer Series Speaker Biographies|publisher=[[San Diego Natural History Museum]]}}</ref>

Schniedewind was the director of the ''Qumran Visualization Project'' (QVP), which created a [[virtual reality]] model of ancient Qumran  under the auspices of UCLA's Experiential Technologies Center (which also has notable projects for 2nd Temple Jerusalem, Islamic Jerusalem, and Ancient Rome).

Schniedewind has participated in excavations and surveys in [[Israel]], including [[Tell es-Safi]], [[Wadi Qumran]], Har Tuv, and [[Tel Batash]],<ref>{{cite web
| title=About the Staff, Qumran Visualization Project
| url=http://www.nelc.ucla.edu/qumran/staff.html}}</ref> and is currently the Associate Director of UCLA's Jaffa Cultural Heritage Project.

== Bibliography ==

* ''The El-Amarna Correspondence (2 Vol. Set): A New Edition of the Cuneiform Letters from the Site of El-Amarna Based on Collations of All Extant Tablets'' (by Anson F. Rainey, volume 1 edited by W. Schniedewind) (Brill, 2014), {{ISBN|9004281452}}
* ''A Primer on Ugaritic: Language, Culture, and Literature'' (with Joel Hunt) (Cambridge, 2007), {{ISBN|978-0-521-87933-0}}

* ''Society and the Promise to David: A Reception History of 2 Samuel 7:1-17'' (Oxford, 1999), {{ISBN|0-19-512680-7}}
* ''The Word of God in Transition: From Prophet to Exegete in the Second Temple Period'' (Sheffield, 1995), {{ISBN|1-85075-550-7}}
